SOLID GROUND It' nu / • i'ikkmm UNIVERSIT Y OF SOUTHER N CALIFORNIA LOS ANGELES, CA 90089-0895 1 9 9 5 EL RO DEO Situated three miles south of the Los Angeles Civic Center, the University Park campus consists of 196 buildings. Older buildings were designed in a traditional style common to other major U.S. universities. University architects insist classic materials such as brick, concrete and tile roofing be incorporated in newer buildings. ON SOLID GROUND Title Page 1 STANDING FIRM Los Angeles fertile ground for our social and academic growth TRADITION - a word that exemplifies our proud phi­ losophy. In keeping with tradition, for the past 114 years we have carried out our founders' vision to make Los Angeles the educational center of the Pacific Coast. We are rooted on the original eight acres of land since our founding in 1880, but have grown to occupy 150 acres of Los Angeles. Despite social and geographic chal­ lenges - the spring 1992 Los Angeles riots, the 1993 Malibu fires, the January 1994 Northridge earthquake - we have rejected opportunites to relocate and remain firmly committed to our area. 2 Opening Larry Ho Doheny Memorial Library was redesigned and now houses an expanded cinema-television library, Doheny remains the center of our library system, holding over 3 million volumes. Completed in 1932, it consists of 168,150 square feet. The Von KleinSmid Center's globe details and identifies our skyline. The center, comprised of the Schools of International Relations and Public Administration, em­ phasizes an international approach to education. VKC is named after Rufus von KleinSmid, university president and chancellor Tommy Trojan has stood at the southeast corner of Bovard Auditorium since June 6,1930. He manifests the Trojan name and spirit associated with USC since we were dubbed Trojans by a Los Angeles Times writer. On his pedestal are inscribed the qualities of an ideal Trojan: faithful, scholarly, skillful, courageous and ambitious. Inside Bovard Administration Building are not only the offices of the president and provost, but also the oldest stage facilities still operating in the Los Angeles area. The Kenneth Norris, Jr. Auditorium is our largest and oldest auditorium. The building was constructed in 1921 and is named for our fourth president George Finley Bovard. "USC is commited to improving the quality of life in our region, and, particularly, in the neighborhoods sur­ rounding our two campuses." - President Steven B. Sample "You can be a part of history here in Los Angeles because there's always something going on, }) - Nicole Willis, junior psychology major "I liked the programs and opportunities offered here. I wanted to go to school in a big city since I grew up in one. » - Hamilton Lancaster, freshman environmental studies major O N SOLID GROUND Jennifer Browning Opening 3 COMMUNITY TIES Fostering services to enrich South Central development In 1991 President Sample said he wanted to expand our local public service programs. The direction of his programs have become quite focused in replant­ ing the university. The Office of Civic and Commu­ nity Relations said 60 percent of stu­ dents volunteer service to the com­ munity at least once a year. The Good Neighbors Campaign asked staff and faculty to contrib= ute to the area. Donations went to further child development and safer neighborhood initiatives. By embracing challenges rather than running from problems, the part­ nership of town and gown will con­ tinue to progress on solid ground. 4 Opening Richard Kim President Steven B. Sample spoke at a dedica­ tion ceremony for Founders Day on October 6. Some 200 people gathered in Founders Park for services. Students Laurie Hill and Adam Strachan, both descendents of founders, unveiled a plaque tracing the origins of campus. University Park Campus is just minutes away from Down­ town Los Angeles. The city was a frontier town when the university opened its doors in 1880. University-Exposi­ tion Park has grown into a major cultural/entertainment area that includes five museums, three galleries and three theatres. Local residents staff many of the dining services on campus. The university is the largest private employer of Los Angeles with 17, 000 full- and part-time employees on both campuses. It also generates some 40,000 jobs out­ side the university. The reference center is Doheny's main reading room. It accommodates 400 students, measures 131 feet long and is two and a half stories high. Marks of 14 printers important in the history of bookmaking are carved in the woodwork and form a frieze around the room. "USC is one of the very few things going for this community - job oppor­ tunities, enrichment pro­ grams for youth. It makes a big difference." - Therese Gacad, junior nursing major "We can no longer depend on corporate philanthropy or govern­ ment to 'fix' our neighborhoods." - Jane Pisano, director of Neigh­ borhood Outreach and chair of USC Good Neighbors Campaign "The whole Latino floor of Fluor Tower decided to join the Joint Educational Project as a group. I found this was so impres­ sive because a lot of them are giving back to the community they grew up in." - Jody Kaufman, senior business admin­ istration, marketing and communications emphasis O N SOLI D GROUND James Su Opening 5 6 Student Life fc HARMONIZING DIVERSITY I n the fast-paced metropolis, our beau­ tiful campus is a haven for eyes beleagured STUDEN T LIFE with smog, The fountain at the intersection of Trousdale Parkway and Childs Way is a favorite place for students to eat lunch, study or just relax. It was a gift from trustee Forrest N. Shumway and his wife Betsy. There are 22 fountains on the main campus. legions of advertisements, or simply a lack of sleep. Brick and plaster used to­ gether throughout the cam­ pus architecture and land­ scaping create classic and con­ temporary harmony, the per­ fect environment for students froml05 countries to look past differences and learn to work together. Student Life 7 Displaying some Trojan history, the university gift shop tells a story about John Robinson at USC. Sweatshirts represented one of the biggest sellers at the bookstore with numerous cat­ egories to select from. TROJAN GEAR All who enter the ground level of the bookstore will quickly see where all the Trojan spirit is. They will also see there is a new look. There are wall to wall para­ phernalia and there are life size posters of football coach John Robinson and women's basketball coach Cheryl Miller, along with former basketball player Harold Miner. One can find anything from USC book bags to Tro­ jan toiletry. All of the ar­ ticles sold are official prod­ ucts of Nike, Russell and Jos tens . During the week many students browse the bookstore for the hottest clothing for the sporting events, "but on the week­ end the alumni are the big­ gest consumer especially during Trojan Family weekends and rivalry games like UCLA and Notre Dame," said Mr. Bowman, manager of the gift shop at the bookstore. According to Mr. Bowman, "the big­ gest selling articles this year are the sunflower products including: sweat shirts, t-shirts, book bags and coffee mugs." For all the USC fans who did not have time to buy all their clothes for the sport­ ing events during the week, there was an official USC booth at the Coliseum. At every home game, one could purchase everything they needed for the game. With this service, there was no reason that everyone could not be showing their Trojan spirit everywhere they go! Article by Monica Ellis. 8 Student Life THE SWOOSH The new hats and jackets that infiltrated this campus all had one thing in common, the Nike swoosh. This famous symbol has come to represent the drive and ability to succeed and has been worn by athletes like Michael Jordan and Gabrielle Reece. Something as simple as this trademark stands for all the hours of prac­ tice, sweat, determination, bravery and heart that go into everything one does. This sym­ bol has now come to represent the excellence that USC in­ stills in its athletes and acade­ micians. Walking in the center of campus a student shows her USC spirit on a back pack. The sunflower products have become one of the biggest selling items at the bookstore according to Mr. Bow­ man, the manager. "Go directly to jail, do not pass go!" USCopoly is one of the unique Trojan items that the bookstore carries. The various places represented on the board include the 901 Club and the Los Ange­ les Coliseum. Finding the perfect shirt or jacket for one's personal USC needs is no prob­ lem at the bookstore. The number and variety of items at the bookstore has increased since Nike has become the official sponsor of the University of Southern California. Laurie Drew Different 'SC Paraphenalia 9 Standing in a pyramid, the USC Yell Leaders call for support from the crowd. One of the Yell Leader traditions is after each score they do as many push-ups as the team has points. 0 I Kayo Goto TROJAN MAN Who is that mysterious man who leads the Trojan March­ ing band on to the field every game? The man behind the armor is Sean Jenkins, drum major for the band. Sean achieved this honor after be­ ing voted in by the band mem­ bers last spring. His official responsibilities are to run the pre-game and halftime shows. When asked what it was like to face a crowd of screaming USC students he said, "I get the biggest lump in my stomach. I take a quick look at the crowd, take a deep breath and then just go into my zone." Kayo Goto Blasting away from the back of the band section, the tuba players provide volume for the USC marching band. The tuba section is also known for their entertaining dance routines during par­ ticular songs. Kayo Goto Completing a routine, the USC Song Leaders pump up the crowd during the Trojan victory over Washington. The Song Leaders, with an eight member squad, cheer at every home football game and some are present at each away game. Kayo Goto 1 0 Student Life Cheering on the football team during the Washington game, the USC Silks offer support for the team. The Silks provide visual entertainment during halftime with their innovative flag rou­ tines. Kayo Goto SC SPIRIT IJVES ON "Fight on for old 'SC! Fight on to victory!" Thousands of screaming devoted fans exhibit their support in a mass of frenzy, chaos and most importantly spirit. Here at the University of Southern California, spirit takes on new meaning. It is a way of life, a part of your soul and identity. Spirit sets USC apart from any other school in the nation. "It's jus t different," claims Emily Parker, a sophomore majoring in critical stud­ ies. "No one else waves two fingers in the air for hours on end to show support. It makes us unique and spe­ cial." . Those two fingers cap­ ture everything USC is about in one small gesture. It unites students from all walks of life, complete strangers who have one common bond. The "V" does not only pertain to athletics, but it defines our goals, hopes and dreams as well. So many people contrib­ ute to keeping spirit alive and well. For example, the sight of the world famous Trojan Marching band sends any devoted USC fan into hysterics. When asked what it felt like to be stand­ ing on the field watching the crazed fans go wild, Nicole Willis, a squad leader for the band who plays alto saxophone, replied simply, "It's intense." The Yell Leaders and Song Leaders also generate spirit, especially at games and pep rallies. With their contagious smiles and crisp, clean uniforms this small bunch knows exactly how to get a crowd on its feet and cheering hard. How does one develop this pride and dedication? "I think they brainwash us with the food," says Megan Outcalt, an exercise science major. "I always knew there was something weird tast­ ing in the food at Cafe 84." The more believable rea­ son is that it is infectious. Generations of Trojans have passed on their pride to their young, as will the students of today do the same. Article by Michelle Ovalle. Spirit Squads 11 Enjoying an afternoon meal in Upper Commons, a couple lingers over their food. Upper Commons was open from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. and provided a more elegant atmosphere for students. Stocking sushi in Commons cafeteria is freshman psychology major Christie Thorneycroft. The sale of food ready to serve and eat has been accommodated by new microwaves in the Commons eating area. Larry Ho Rushing to his destination a student grabs a bite to eat. The shelves stocked with various items were all part of the refurbished Commons area. Larry Ho A NEW LOOK The refurbished Commons area was one of the most wel­ come additions to the campus in 1994. The renovated din­ ing room and newly designed market area were opened up to give the appearance of more space and the furnishings were decorated with light colors as opposed to the dark brown that was present before. The products offered in the refur­ bished Commons allowed stu­ dents to enjoy a greater vari­ ety of items. Sophia Molinaro, a junior art history major en­ joys one of the food stuffs at Commons, a soup bar. Larry Ho 1 2 Student Life A MOVEAB L E F EAST Cafeteria food at most universities is not some­ thing that people usually look forward to, but at USC we have the privilege of di­ verse choices of good food. Commons Cafeteria is one of the most visited spots because of its location in the center of campus. People have their choice from a variety of breakfast and lunch items as well as specialty items like min­ eral waters and sushi. Over the summer, Commons was remodeled and the main dining room's brightly painted walls and new car­ pets welcomed people to sit down and enjoy their food. When students walked into the refurbished area they were greeted by baskets of candy and shelves layered with fresh pastries and fruit. If students were in the mood for a sit down lunch with table side service they needed only to go to the Upstairs Commons for their meal. This restaurant of­ fered pastas, hot sand­ wiches, appetizers and de­ licious desserts. Complimenting these ser­ vices were more specialized dining establishments like Wolfgang Puck's California Pizza. This world famous pizzeria opened on campus in 1993 and provided an­ other place to eat. The Ground Zero Coffee House, another recent ad­ dition to the USC campus, provided an environment for students to meet each other and get a cup of good coffee. Ground Zero offered poetry and play readings and every Thursday there were jazz performances. Local bands also came to perform and special events like Casino Night took place there as well. Ground Zero also underwent renovation recently with the addition of a new stage, new cur­ tains and ceiling fans. These restaurants, along with Carl's Junior, Cafe 84 and the Grill comprised a dining program that was unique to this campus and which gave a wide variety of choices for both students and faculty to enjoy. Ar­ ticle by Christie Russell. Receiving a piece of world famous pizza graduate student Marcelo Adrian D'Asero prepares to eat lunch. Wolfgang Puck's opened on campus in 1993 providing yet another place to grab some good food. Larry Ho Eateries on Campus 13 Cheering on the Trojan football team, a throng of USC students watches the game against Cal. The Trojans humili­ ated the Golden Bears 61 -0 for the first shut-out of the season. TROJAN TRADITIONS This university has been founded upon tradition and a legacy of success. This feeling of tradition has been passed from generation to generation of students at USC and has helped create the idea of a Trojan family. With the continuation of this spirit throughout the years there have been cer­ tain actions and words that have become part of the Trojan tradition. "I came to USC because of the tradition, nowhere else is there the feeling of a Trojan family and USC has some of the best alumni support in the nation," said Jennifer Jackson, a fresh­ man majoring in history. The University of South­ ern California did not al­ ways have the Trojan as its mascot. The name origi­ nated from a 1912 article in the Los Angeles Times in which Owen Bird, describ­ ing the USC athletes at a track meet, said they, "fought like Trojans." Since that time the name has be­ come a part of the USC tra­ dition. The USC slogan "Fight On!" is derived from the fight song written by USC studentMilo Sweet in 1922. Those words have come to embody the spirit and dedi­ cation that USC has for its athletics and academics. The formal traditions at USC are accompanied by many actions that cannot be traced to any single event. The two fingers thrust into the air is a com­ mon signal that has been adapted to represent Tro­ jan victory and pride in USC. One of the more obscure traditions is the kicking of the flag poles as students and alumni walk to the Coliseum for football games. The bottom of the flag poles are kicked before the game for good luck and after a winning game to cel­ ebrate the victory. No one is really sure where this came from but nonetheless it has become of the Trojan tradition. It is the combi­ nation of formal traditions with those everyday activi­ ties which keep the spirit and tradition of the Univer­ sity of Southern California alive and well. Article by Joseph Carmona. 14 Student Life Julie Gargan RING MY BEU Most students have either seen or heard about the infa­ mous "bell man." While his identity is unknown his deeds are quite the opposite. This dedicated fan can be seen run­ ning up and down the bleach­ ers urging students to do a SoCal spellout. With the ring­ ing of his bell and his over­ whelming enthusiasm stu­ dents cannot help but comply with his requests and start the famous, "S-o-u..." With every letter the spirit in the crowd builds until the final scream of the school's name and the "bell man" moves on to another part of the crowd, his task accom­ plished. Taking a piece out of the flag pole, an alumnus participates in the pregame tradition. The kicking of the flag pole is done both before and after the game to bring luck and to celebrate a victory. Julie Gargan Julie Gargan Showing support for USC, this student wears the traditional cardinal and gold. Cardinal and gold were chosen as the official school colors in 1895 taking the selection from the original school color, gold, and from the College of Liberal Arts official color at the time, cardinal. Julie Gargan Grinding out some push-ups, the Yell Leaders show some of their game time traditions. The Yell Leaders do as many push-ups as thefootball team has points and they were hard pressed on this day as the team defeated Cal 61 -0. Julie Gargan University Traditions 15 Displaying his two tattoos is Charles Cunn, a sophomore Cinema produc­ tion major. He explained that his tattoos are a way of expressing himself and that he plans on getting more in the future. Showing off her lion tattoo, Melissa Mandrgoc also has a pierced belly but­ ton. Mandrgoc "thought about it a lot" before proceeding to get her tattoo. "This is something permanent, and I wanted to make sure." Showing off his ankle tattoo is Cory Bunyard, a sophomore who is unde­ clared. He claimed that the tattoo hurt less than he had expected. 16 Student Life MAKING A CHANGE Some people wear eccen­ tric shoes, some don out­ landish hats, and others put on colored contacts. These are a few of the diversified manners that students at USC present daily. How­ ever, a few students took a further daring step - body alteration. "Lots of people did not expect this of me. I did it as a shocker, I guess. And it worked," explained Soniya Deshpande, who decided to go ahead with a nose ring during spring break in her freshman year. The motives for body al­ terations differed for each person. To some students it was a display of individu­ ality. For others, the alter­ ation itself may hold spe­ cial meaning. Melissa Mandrgoc chose Leo, her astrological sign, to be her tattoo. "It (astrology) is the only thing I believe in," she explained. In addition, one has to think about cost and safety when considering a body alteration. The price range varies greatly from $15 for nose rings to over $100 for tattoos. Body alterations often involve working with needles. Thus, the major health concern is that clean, sterile needles are used to minimize transmit­ ting disease. Furthermore, great care must be taken to clean the altered area to prevent infection. Shoes, hats, and contacts can be removed at the end of the day. Body alterations such as tattoos, colored hair, and nose rings, how­ ever, are here to stay. For this reason, the decision to undertake such a drastic change requires careful consideration. Mandrgoc "thought about it a lot" be­ fore proceeding to get her tattoo. "This is something permanent, and I wanted to make sure." For some students, how­ ever, the alteration is tem­ porary rather than perma­ nent. Deshpande ruefully anticipates that her nose ring probably will have to close after college. "I am pre-med. How would you like a doctor with a nose ring to come up to you?" Article by Jing Chen. IT'S PERSONAL The extent to which body piercing has become a part of certain people's lives amazes some. The recent explosion of body piercing has some claim­ ing that it is simply a fad and will soon pass from the cul­ tural scene. However, Kristin Ruger, a theatre major, claims that getting her tongue, nose, eyebrows and various parts of her body pierced has nothing to do with a trend but rather a form of self-expression. What­ ever the personal reason for body piercing it remains one of the most interesting forms of body alteration. Basking in the sun is one of USC's premier volleyball players, Meika Wagner, who is a senior majoring in political science. She claimed getting her ears pierced hurt more than when she got her belly button pierced. Body Alteration 17 Standing imposingly, the Leavey Library was completed priorto the beginning of the school year with the landscaping added as the year progressed. The final cost of the library was over 27 million. WAVE OF THE FUTURE The final cost of the new teaching library on the Uni­ versity of Southern Califor­ nia campus is $2 7.5 million The primary role Leavey Library serves is to act as an internal center for un­ dergraduates. The theory that the library is built upon says that students who have skill in print and electronic information have a com­ petitive edge in our infor­ mation based economy. The library also acts as a method through which in­ formation technology can be brought into the class­ room. Dr. Christopher Fergusen, director of Leavey Library says that the "instructional research support for undergradu­ ates" promotes excellence in education, and he be­ lieves that this can be found at Leavey Library. Dr. Fergusen says that workshops and classes are offered throughout the se­ mester. These classes are published in the class schedule, and are offered 10 to 20 times a week. These workshops teach students how to use computers, USC info, and much more. The workshops were created to aid those students who have little or no experience deal­ ing with the different com­ ponents that Leavey library has to offer. The library has eight li­ brarians, eight library as­ sistants, several computer consultants, and many stu­ dent employees. The librar­ ians' main focus is to con­ tribute to the instruction, research, consultation and collection that goes on within the library. The li­ brary assistants contribute to the operation of the ser­ vice desk and the naviga­ tion assistance program in the Information Commons. Future plans for the li­ brary include access to 350 magazines and journals as well as an electronic reserve service which is scanned and made available elec­ tronically by audio or by images. As technology ad­ vances and changes, major changes will occur through­ out the library. Says Dr. Chris Fergusen, "we are prepared to take full advan­ tage of all that." Article by Samantha Kerdman. 18 Student Life I I pit i ! 7 7 Laurie Drew NEW IDEAS The students pictured here are part of a new wave of li­ braries. Peter Lyman, the ex­ ecutive director of the Center for Scholarly Technology at USC, wrote an article entitled "The Library of the (Not-So- Distant) Future." He believes the library system needs to be recreated because of the rising cost of printed materials, the volume of information avail­ able and new technology that cannot be printed on paper. These ideas led to the new structures that form the Tho­ mas and Dorothy Leavey Li­ brary. Welcoming students to the recently finished library, an archway covers the entrance. The landscaping in front of the library was not completed until af­ ter it had already opened its doors. I Asking for assistance, a student gets help from the front desk. Upon entering the library, there is a lobby that leads to the various areas of the building. Finding a little peace and quiet, a stu­ dent studies diligently. The library has three levels not including the basement which contains the Information Com­ mons. Leavey Library 19 D'AnnWeita, a junior majoring in broad­ cast journalism, listens to an explana­ tion in Spanish I. D'Ann transfered to USC this year from Pasadena City College. Julie Gargan FITTING IN Heather Moos is one student who has decided to make the most of her time at USC. She is the founder of the Student Parenting Network. This orga­ nization provides support and services for students with chil­ dren. Heather claimed that she felt alienated from other stu­ dents and wanted to create an atmosphere where she could meet persons like herself. Heather stated that she was a "parent first and student sec­ ond" and that this organiza­ tion helps her feel more a part of the Trojan family. Julie Gargan Thirty-two year old Nancy Whelan adds fliers to her wall. Nancy returned to school to pursue a triple major in psy­ chology, marine biology and physical therapy. Nancy returned to school at thirty because, "I got tired of hitting glass ceilings and I wanted to do some­ thing productive." Julie Gargan Relaxing for a moment together are Heather Crew and Troy Johnson. Heather is a sophomore majoring in theatre and Troy is a sophomore in philosophy. Julie Gargan 2 0 Student Life Transfer student Dewayne Jones, a jun­ ior majoring in communications, enjoys a Beverly Hills 90210 evening with friend Melanie Dimmick. Dewayne transfered from from East Carolina University be­ cause, "I lived on the East coast all my life and I wanted to come out to the West coast." Julie Gargan BREAKING THE MOLD The University of South­ ern California is a college that is based upon tradi­ tion. A historic devotion to academic and athletic ex­ cellence are the founda­ tions upon which these tra­ ditions are laid. The tradi­ tional students were single 18-22 year male and fe­ males who started school here and will finish it here. However, there were sev­ eral groups of students on campus that were non-tra­ ditional. Single parents, re­ turning students and trans­ fer students were just a few of the non-traditional types of people that attended this university. Single parents represent a population that has risen in number over the last few years, and presence of a student parenting group on campus acknowledges this fact. Returning students range in age anywhere from 25 to 70 years old and come back to go to graduate school or to earn a degree that they never had a chance to get. Transfer students repre­ sented an extremely unique population on campus. These students were usu­ ally older than the average incoming freshmen but with the same questions that a new student would have. The difficulties that arise from this situation often leave most students feeling confused and intimi­ dated. There were several other groups that faced chal­ lenges on campus as well including disabled stu­ dents, international stu­ dents and minority stu­ dents. Each of these groups had their own type of orga­ nizations to provide advice and offer support. The obstacles that many non-traditional students faced were lessened by the presence of many organi­ zations on campus and the personal strength that these students possess al­ lowed them to overcome the boundaries that tradi­ tion sometimes creates. Article by Joseph Gar- mona. Non-traditional Students 21 Talking leisurely between takes, "Party of Five" crew members anticipate the next scene. The filming occupied most of Alumni park and a considerable amount of Trousdale Parkway. Stationed by the mixing board, a mem­ ber of the crew for the television show "Party of Five" waits for the action to begin. The filming took place on Octo­ ber 25th on Trousdale Parkway. Oh, to direct. To put faces and images on film and have them be an expression of an original vision is the dream of many students. The Cinema- television school is considered one of, if not, the finest in the nation and students come to Los Angeles and Hollywood to fulfill their dreams of making it in show business. "I came to USC because of the film school. Its location and support by the industry make it the best place to begin a career in film," said Lee Farber, a junior majoring in cinema-television. ,#t H 2 2 Student Life FAMILIAR PLACES You're watching "90210," enjoying the Beverly Hills gang's ridiculous attempts to play a prank on their rival school in honor of the big homecoming game. Suddenly you stop laugh­ ing—something about that rival school looks familiar. The network cuts to a com­ mercial break. One of the "Got Milk?" ads comes on. As you smile at the frus­ trated priest who kicks and pounds on a vending ma­ chine in a deserted corri­ dor, you can't help bu t won­ der where you've seen that hallway before. You shrug and slide your copy of "Forrest Gump" into the VGR. Wait a minute. Are you imagining things or does Jenny's dorm look a lot like Marks Hall? Relax, you're not due for a padded cell, and, no, you haven't overdosed on Tro­ jan pride. Chances are, if it looks like USG on the screen, it probably is. "This campus has been featured in everything from movies to television shows to commercials and photo layouts," said Victoria Daves, the filming coordi­ nator for the USG Commu­ nications Office. The university's film credits included "The Graduate," "Marathon Man," "Gross Anatomy," "The Paper Chase," "City Slickers 2," "The Mighty Ducks 2," and "Blue Chips." USG was also featured in episodes of "Party of Five," "Sweet Justice," and "Tales From the Crypt," and photo layouts for Speedo, Nike, "Shape" magazine, and the Broadway fall catalogue. "I think production crews like our campus because the buildings are old and interesting to look at. They have that East Coast look," said location liaison David Giannovario. "Plus, our proximity to the studios makes us an appealing choice." The communications of­ fice, with its staff of three, fielded constant requests for on-campus sites from location scouts every day and made arrangements to accommodate an average of one film crew per week, Daves said. Article by Nne Ebong. Adjusting a lighting fixture, crew mem­ bers prepare for a scene. The filming of a "Party of Five" included many stu­ dents as extras. Andrew Pupius Filming on Campus 23 LOOKING FOR GOD You are walking across campus, heading to your next class or on your way home and you hear some­ one speaking through a microphone. You casually listen to the person's pow­ erful story of how they have found the Lord and how their life has been for­ ever changed. Scenes like these are not uncommon on campus. There are over 20 officially recognized religious orga­ nizations at USG; some of the more visible ones are the Campus Crusade for Christ and the Trojan Vic­ tory Fellowship. These or­ ganizations serve many spiritual purposes on cam­ pus. Dennis Tuma, direc­ tor of the Campus Crusade for Christ said, "our goal is to show students and fac­ ulty God's purpose for our lives and to help them think through the person of Jesus Christ." His group held many activities on campus including study groups, Thursday night meetings and forums interacting with students. Tuma said these various activities serve to "give the Christian perspec­ tive and to demonstrate how Jesus Christ has chang­ ed our lives." Organizations like the Campus Crusade for Christ genuinely try to help stu­ dents and provide them with a valuable service. However, there are organi­ zations that students be­ come involved in that do not serve their best inter­ ests. In recent years there has been a rise in the amount of activity from these unsanctioned groups. They prey upon the disori­ entation and hopelessness that many students face in college. The university has instituted several policies to deal with these groups and students should be aware of the existence of these types of organiza­ tions. Article by Joseph Garmona. Illustrating his points with examples from the bible, speaker Brian Burchell speaks to members of the Campus Cru­ sade for Christ. The group held numer­ ous activities including Bible studies and forums. 24 Student Life Sharing a Bible, these two students follow along as speaker Brian Burchell reads a passage. The Campus Crusade for Christ held various forums over the year to teach students about Jesus Christ. Speaking to members of the Korean American Campus Mission, guest speaker Jim Jung consults the Bible. The decades of the 20s and 30s saw the arrival of such important buildings as Bovard Auditorium, Doheny Library, Mudd Hall of Philosophy, the Physical Education Building and the Student Union Building. The 60s and 70s were another expansive time in the university's existence. The Von Kleinsmid Center and Heritage Hall became part of the campus scene adding their impressive ar­ chitecture to the college. Seaver Science Center, the Mont­ gomery Ross Fischer Build­ ing, Ray and Nadine Watt Hall of Architecture and Fine Arts, the Eileen Norris Cinema Theatre and the Annenberg School of Com­ munication all became part of the university campus and were reflections of the prosperity and continued growth of USG. EE RODEO : A 90 YEAR El Rodeo (pronounced EL-RO-DAY-OH) has been the university's official yearbook since 1898, when the junior class published a 7 1/2 x 10 inch annual as a gift for the senior class of 1898. The book has been produced regularly every year since 1908. Its predecessor was the Sibyl, an even smaller book at 6 3/4 x 10 inches. The Sibyl was printed only once in June 1889 with a paper cover. "The yearbook was not the first publication to carry the El Rodeo name," said Susan Hikida, assistant uni­ versity archivist. Students put out what was probably al6-page newsletter in 1891 called El Rodeo. But from where did the 1898 staff of five obtain the name? No one really knows, said Hikida. Two stories have circulated over the years: the common one says the title referred to the ru­ ral area on which the uni­ versity was built, while an­ other says it was named to commemorate a campus celebration that was called El Rodeo. The first of the full-sized versions was produced in 1925 with 560 pages. That year two editions were available - one reflected the popularl920s Oriental theme, the other was de­ signed around a Spanish theme, which was probably inspired by the El Rodeo name. Contests promoted the "complete contemporane­ ous history of the current university year," and ads proclaiming u El Rod is here" ran in the Daily Tro­ jan. Past books have been awarded All-American and first-class ratings by the National Scholastic Press Association. The 1990 edi­ tion won the Pacemaker Award, college media's highest honor. The yearbook's staff has 40 Student Life A staff of five was large enough to put outthefirstE/ftodeo. They were CE.D. Ballou, editor, Bertha Green and F.G.H.S. Stevens, assistant editors, Philo Jones, business manager, and William F. Lloyd, illustrator. Modern staffs now comprise over 40 students. /l#7l 7 Julie Gargan EEGACY grown from the original five to the current 40, and has evolved from using paste­ up techniques to the Macintosh computer sys­ tem. Staff members follow a section format that has been used since the book's inception. Editors spend as many as 30 hours per week in the yearbook offices, juggling classes and work. They, along with student writers, layout artists and photog­ raphers assemble the book with the assistance of full- time staff. Limited funding, produc­ tion difficulties, and lack of student interest have plagu­ ed yearbook production at major campuses through­ out the nation in recent years. Many institutions have opted for quarterly magazines instead of a single yearbook. But this staff hopes El Rod will en­ dure another 90 years. Academics 43 Structural Changes In LAS With Appointment Of New Dean HAPIRO REORGANIZES As the university and community at large reorga­ nized themselves on more solid ground, so also did the College of Letters, Arts and Sciences with the an­ nouncement of a new dean, Dr. Morton Shapiro, who implemented organizational changes during the sum­ mer break. In an in-depth interview printed in the September 12 edition of the USC Chronicle, Shapiro outlined many of the changes which took effect. Chief among these changes was a move from a divisional dean structure to one of functional deans. The result was the dissemination of many departments with special inter­ est deans to a more cohesive single college. According to Shapiro, this was a sign of faith in the ability of the departments to handle their own day to day opera­ tions. "My feeling is that our departments are at a level now that we can really step back and give them greater autonomy. If the direction they're going is not consis­ tent with the direction we want them to go, we have all kinds of options. But my general philosophy is much more hands-off. Let the faculty and department chairs make the decisions. I think people should make the decisions at the level where they have the most knowl­ edge/' The office of deans is broken into three areas of supervision. The dean of the faculty, Joseph Aoun, supervises salaries, hiring and promotions. The dean of research, Maria Pellegrini, interfaces with research donors and supervises unsponsored research as well. The third area, which entails the supervision of cur­ riculum and instruction, is handled by Dean Nancy Vickers. According to Shapiro, the move to Bovard has had numerous positive effects. "We're all in one office. We used to have four suites, now we're all together. It's worked out beautifully for a number of reasons. It makes it much easier to interact, and it's conducive to an atmosphere that I really want to foster - one of cooperation, not of people controlling different fiefdoms and arguing against each other. We're all looking out for the greater good of the college. We don't always agree perfectly on everything, but it's not set up at all in an adversarial way, which often happens in a divisional structure." Annenberg Expansion 47 CNTV Students and Alumni Dominate Film Industry Since 1929 ES T IN THE BUSINESS The School of Cinema-Television celebrated its 65 th anniversary in 1994. From its beginning in 1929, CNTV has remained an important force in the education of filmmakers. Every year since 1950 at least one USC graduate has received an Academy Award nomination, proving the great impact the USC Cinema-Television School has had on the film industry 7 . Out of the 12 highest grossing films in history, 10 have had cinema school alumni as part of the creative and production teams. "USC alumni have created a remarkable legacy, and have had an indelible impact on the art of the moving image," wrote Dean Elizabeth M. Daley in the premier edition of the school's newletter, "In Motion," last spring. "It is impossible to imagine what the Hollywood film and television industry would be like today without the contributions of USC alumni." Several activities have taken place to celebrate the school's 65th anniversary. First of all, the school initi­ ated the USC Award for Leadership in the Entertain­ ment Industry. Cinema-Television School*s 65th Anniversary 49 5 0 Academics Exceptional Professors Dedicated to Advancing Education ISTINGUISHING IMPRESSIONS The University of Southern California boasts some of the most renown and distinguished professors in the world. Many of these professors have left positive impressions on their students as well as others in the international scholarly community. They continually strive to position LISC as an institution for academic excellence and a leader in private research. Of the many outstanding professors at USC, there are three who are noted for their dedication to research and their quest for educating others. Dr. Warren Bennis is recognized as a Distinguished Professor of Business Administration. His contribu­ tions include two best-selling books, Leaders and On Becoming a Leader. In addition to teaching, Dr. Bennis is currently one of the most popular lecturers on the corporate consulting circuit. He has also re­ ceived eight honorary degrees and has been recog­ nized with two prestigious national awards. Dr. Bennis has created a life full of power and prestige for himself and is known as one of the foremost business leaders in the nation. Al Gore even quotes him and had Bennis conduct a day-long seminar for his Washington staff. Dr. Adrian Raine is a Professor of Psychology and has been studying the biological bases of antisocial behavior for the past seventeen years. Dr. Raine re­ cently published a book comprehensively summariz­ ing his findings entitled The Psyehopathology of Crime. His studies are of great value, for they suggest that better health care at birth may prevent some children from becoming violent criminals. Dr. Leonard Adleman is a Professor of Computer Science whose main research activities are in theoreti­ cal computer science. Dr. Adleman is well-known for his work on cryptography and as one of the discoverers of the RSA (Rivest-Shamir-Adleman) coding system. His experiments on adapting DNA molecules to pro­ cess information have attracted international attention and praise. His studies show that molecular computers might be as much as a billion times more energy 7 efficient than current electronic computers. Students have the opportunities of taking classes from such distinguished professors and learning from their experiences. It is the great professors such as Bennis, Raine, and Adleman that will position USC as one of the most academically competitive universities in the future. Impressive Professors 51 Minh Pham First Nobel Prize Adds Academic Recognition HEMIST WINS PRIZE Dr. George Olah sat at the head of his conference table, wide eyes penetrating, open-palmed hand mo­ tions stressing critical details. "I have a very happy life," he said. "Besides having a wonderful family, I am able to do what I love to do all my life, which is research and connected teaching. And they even pay me to do these things." With his humble disposition, Olah could easily be perceived as an average man content with his life and his work, and not as the man whose 40-year passion for science won him the 1994 Nobel Prize in Chemisty. Olah was the sole recipient of the award, which honored his research in the use of superacids, a trillion times more acidic than sulfuric acid, in effectively freezing chemical reactions, said G. K. Surya Prakash, associate professor of chemistry and one of Olah's associates. His research allowed scientists to study the intermmediate stages and products of the reactions. "I am very proud that USC may be remembered also for science, and not just for football. I admire college athletics, but there must be balance in a school," he said. "I think we have a fine school here; USC is becoming a world class major university. Maybe my recognition also adds a little to USC's well deserved recognition." Most of his research had been conducted at the Donald P. and Katherine B. Loker Hydrocarbon Re­ search Institute. Several years ago with a few of his colleagues, he founded the institute and is serving his 18th year as director. "I consider myself a very active teacher and researcher." Olah has been honored with numerous other awards including the Chemical Pioneers Award by the Ameri­ can Institute of Chemists, Inc. "I am an immigrant to this country. I found really a new home. To me, this is still the country with unlim­ ited possibilities. You must work for it, and maybe you must work harder than 20 years ago." Educated hi Budapest, Hungary, he began his re­ search on hydrocarbons and superacids in the late 1950s, bu t today insists that his work is still unfinished. "It's like discovering a new continent, there's a lot to be done. With my students and associates we are continuing to explore this wonderful field." Professor Wins Nobel Prize for Chemistry 53 Superhighway Links USC Students To The World OAD TO INFORMATION Highway 101 wasn't the only place you could run into heavy traffic this year. Thousands of people across the world, and USC, had discovered a new 7 highway that could take them anywhere they wanted to go in a matter of seconds: the information superhighway. A term coined by vice-president Al Gore, the informa­ tion superhighway described a national information infrastructure that, when completed, would allow high­ speed transmission of digitized video, sound, graphics and text via computer to every home an d business in the United States. USC students got a chance to ride this new wave of technology through the Internet. Access to the net was free to all students onee they signed on for an e-mail account. For newbies, those unfamiliar with the Internet system, University Computing Services provided courses designed to show new users how to avoid becoming superhighway roadkill. The School of Journalism offered "Navigating the Information Superhighway," a course that served as an introduction to using on-line computer services to gather and disseminate information. Course instructor Dr. Carolyn Cline said she hoped that the new class would become a permanent part of the journalism curriculum. "For journalists, the highway is the future," Cline said. "Even if the online media fail, and some will, the net has changed research forever, making much more information available to journalists even in small cities miles from decent libraries. It's also making informa­ tion available much faster than ever before." Despite the many obvious advantages of the net, there were a few drawbacks to the system, "It can be intensely frustrating to try to navigate, especially when you realize that certain areas are not well covered on the net yet," said Cline, who pointed out that as the public's knowledge of online services expanded, so did the need for information providers on the net. "Like a crowded highway, there are sometimes vir­ tual traffic jams," Cline sighed. "They call it netlag." Information Superhighway 55 Jennifer Browning Field Trips Are A Vehicle For Learning At USC EYOND LECTURES Learning by doing, so the motto goes. To expand students' learning experience beyond the walls of the classrooms, many courses integrated field trips into their curriculum. Students were offered the opportu­ nity to apply their newly gained knowledge to the real world. In Geology 109, Professor Lund led his students to the shore lines of San Pedro. Here students observed firsthand the many rock formations they studied in class. In addition, they examined the many earthquake fault lines around the area. Professor Anderson and his students from the fresh­ man seminar "Only One Earth" headed for the Mohave Desert for a weekend excursion in November. Along the way, students stopped by a few of the countless fault lines in the desert area, including the San Andreas and the Cueamonga faults. The trip included a short hike in the desert and the opportunity 7 to scale a sand dune. In addition, the students visited a few of the dead volcanoes. For most students, this was their first time visiting the Mohave Desert. "I never knew that we had volcanoes near the desert!" said Michelle Rodriguez. "I was sick and was thinking of not going. But I am glad that I went. It was fun." Students from Biology 106 and 116 were introduced to marine life forms in tide pools on their trip to the San Pedro beach. Under the guidance of graduate students, students discovered a myriad of sea creatures such as clams, periwinkles, sea anemones, and sea stars along the rocky shores. Many students found the trip educational as well as enjoyable. Freshman Lillian Co thought the trip was "much more fun and a better learning experience" than the weeldy biology labs. "It was neat to see them [sea creatures] in their natural environment and to see them moving." Jeff Wachner Services that Help You Decide on a Major 63 USC Scholars Are Guaranteed Admission To Medical School ED SCHOOL FOR ME Sixty-six students found themselves one step closer to their aspirations in the health care profession when US C made them an offer they couldn't refuse: guaran­ teed admission into the USC med school. Created in 1993, the Baccalaureate M.D. program accepted no more than 35 high school seniors per year based on applicants' GPAs and SAT scores. Students who maintained a 3.2 GPA throughout their under­ graduate studies and scored an eight or higher on the MCA T were automatically admitted into the USC med school, one of the top 20 medical schools in the nation. "I read about the program in the USC application and I knew that I wanted to go to med school anyway, so I decided to try it," said Loren Geller, a freshman majoring in biology. "It sounded like a really good opportunity." Formerly known as the B.A.M.D., the program's name was changed to the Baccalaureate M.D. to allow students to pursue either a B.A. or B.S. degree in their undergraduate coursework. "This way they don't have to major in a science if they don't want to," said program assistant Gina Zavala. "They can pursue a broader education." In addition to their pre-med course requirements, freshmen and sophomores in the program were re­ quired to take "Intro to Health Professions," a course that provided them the opportunity to meet with guest speakers from different areas in the health care profes­ sion. Craig Rohan, a sophomore majoring in biomedical engineering, considered the additional course a bo­ nus. "The admission guarantee is nice, but obviously, being able to take a med school-type class as an undergrad is a great advantage," Rohan said. Students in the course were also allowed to shadow a different clinical physician twice each semester and meet with patients. "The students love it," said Zavala. "That, in my opinion, is the best part of the class." Article by Nne Ebong. 6 4 Academics Sophomore Craig Rohan relaxes in front of the USC University Hospital. BAMD 65 Jennifer Browning Students Complete Final Year Of High School At USC ARLY ARRIVALS Among the thousands of freshmen that entered USC this year, about fifty of them had not yet completed their senior year of high school. These students were part of the Residential Housing Program. Through RHP exceptional high school students were admitted to the university one year early. These students then completed their senior year of high school and fresh­ man year of college simultaneously here at USC. The students in the RHP program were comprised of diverse individuals. They came from many parts of the nation to pursue various fields such as english, engi­ neering, international relations, and the natural sci­ ences. All RHP students were recipients of either the Dean's Scholarship or the Trustee Scholarship. They were required, for the first year, to stay in either Marks Hall or Trojan Hall, the designated dean's halls. In addition, the students participated in the rigorous Thematic Option program. Many of the RHP students had demanding high school schedules far more challenging than those taken by their classmates. By the end of their junior years in high school, these students had outgrown their high schools. Juliane Roffers, who took many honors courses and BC calculus last year at her high school in Wisconsin, explained, "most of my courses this year would have been at college level anyway, like Calculus III and AP courses." Like most of their older freshmen counterparts, the RHP students found college to be a place very different from high school. The obvious change was the increas­ ing sense of freedom in their daily lives. "People here don't care if you don't come to class. But if you go, they pay more attention to you," commented Roffers. Many students enjoyed the wide variety of classes offered here and the liberty in scheduling them. Most RHPs described their first year experience to be challenging and enjoyable. They found that college courses demanded more effort than those in high school. However, there was also time for new friend­ ships to develop and to explore new places. Looking back upon her decision to attend USC a year in advance, junior Alice Flory declared her choice to be "positively" right for her.
